{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} [[Brigadier]] '''John Ormsby Evelyn 'JOE' Vandeleur''' [[Distinguished Service Order|DSO]] and Bar, [[Order of Orange-Nassau|ON]] (14 November 1903 – 4 August 1988) was a [[British Army]] officer who served in the [[Second World War]]. ==Early life== His family was originally from [[Kilrush]], [[County Clare]], where they were the local landlords. Vandeleur was born in [[Nowshera, Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa|Nowshera]], [[India]] (now [[Pakistan]]).[http://www.unithistories.com/officers/Army_officers_V01.html#Vandeleur_JOE Army Record] ==Military career== He was commissioned into the [[Irish Guards]] as a 2nd Lieutenant in 1924, serving in [[Sudan]] and [[Egypt]] before the war. As [[Commanding Officer]] of 3rd Battalion Irish Guards he led the breakout of [[XXX Corps (United Kingdom)|XXX Corps]] during [[Operation Market-Garden]]. His second cousin Lieutenant-Colonel [[Giles Vandeleur]] (their grandfathers were brothers) was acting Commanding Officer of the 2nd Armoured Battalion Irish Guards.[http://www.unithistories.com/officers/Army_officers_V01.html#Vandeleur_GAM Army Record] He went on to command the [[British 129th Infantry Brigade|129th Brigade]] and [[British 32nd Infantry Brigade (Guards)|32nd Brigade]]. He retired from the Army in 1951. His memoirs ''A Soldier's Story'' were privately printed by [[Gale & Polden]] in 1967.[http://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B0018G0XA2 ''A Soldier's Story''] www.Amazon.co.uk In the 1977 film ''[[A Bridge Too Far (1977 film)|A Bridge Too Far]]'', [[Michael Caine]] played J.O.E.[http://www.allmovie.com/work/7107 All Movie] and [[Michael Byrne (actor)|Michael Byrne]] played Giles Vandeleur. Brigadier Vandeleur (ret.) acted as Military Consultant to the production. He lived out his life after the war in a magnificent manor house in [[Pinkneys Green]], near [[Maidenhead]] in [[Berkshire]]. Vandeleur died in [[Maidenhead]], England in 1988. He is buried in [[Brookwood Cemetery]]. His grave is marked by a simple headstone inscribed only "J.O.E. V 1903 - 1988" and underneath "Once an Irish Guardsman". ==See also== [[Joe's Bridge]] — is the nickname given to Bridge No.9 on the [[Meuse River|Maas]]–[[Scheldt]] Canal in the Belgian city of [[Lommel]] just south of the Belgian–Dutch border. ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.irish-guards.co.uk/neerpelt.htm Irish Guards site] *[http://www.bbc.co.uk/ww2peopleswar/stories/83/a4544183.shtml WW2 – A Peoples War]
